title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: Observations reveal that Aspergillus bridgerii, an endophytic fungus, has been found to degrade nonwoven fabric in surgical masks at an accelerated rate within microcosms. This degradation is attributed to the fungus's ability to secrete enzymes that break down the polypropylene and polyethylene components of the fabric. The microcosms, which consisted of controlled environments with artificial sunlight, temperature, and humidity, allowed for the isolation of the fungus's effects, demonstrating that it can thrive in the presence of these industrial materials. Studies have shown that A. bridgerii's enzymatic activity can lead to the disintegration of the fabric within 30 days, raising concerns about the long-term stability of nonwoven materials in the environment. The findings suggest that Aspergillus bridgerii can adapt to and exploit the chemical properties of industrial materials, highlighting the potential for microbial degradation of human infrastructure.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: Observations indicate that the presence of mold and air fresheners in indoor environments often leads to the formation of unforeseen toxicological interactions. These interactions involve the colonization of mold on industrial air freshener materials, resulting in the production of novel mycotoxins. The release of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from air fresheners is found to enhance mold growth and promote the production of these mycotoxins. This multispecies assemblage is observed to produce synergistic effects, resulting in increased concentrations of airborne toxicants that exceed human exposure limits. The breakdown of air freshener materials by mold enzymes is also noted, leading to the release of previously contained chemicals into the indoor environment.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: Observations of postharvest tomato storage facilities reveal an increased presence of Alternaria alternata, a fungal pathogen causing significant economic losses in the agricultural industry. Ligusticum jeholense essential oil demonstrated an antifungal mechanism against A. alternata, inhibiting mycelial growth and reducing mycotoxin production by up to 45%. The essential oil's efficacy against A. alternata can be attributed to the presence of ligustilide and butylphthalide, which exhibit antimicrobial properties. In a controlled environment, volatile compounds released by L. jeholense essential oil diffused through the storage area, effectively reducing fungal growth on tomato surfaces. Further research is warranted to elucidate the complex interactions between plant-derived essential oils and postharvest fungal pathogens, and to explore potential applications for mycotoxin control in the agricultural industry.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Observations of Industrial Ecosystems:  In certain areas impacted by human infrastructure, novel interspecies relationships have emerged. Industrial materials such as nanomaterial-enabled catalysts have triggered unexpected responses from nonhuman entities, including fungi, bacteria, and toxins. Microorganisms have begun to utilize these materials for their own metabolic purposes, catalyzing chemical reactions that exceed human design. Fungi, for instance, have been observed to colonize and degrade industrial materials, liberating bound toxins and reconstituting the chemical landscape. Conversely, bacteria and other microorganisms have formed symbiotic relationships with these materials, generating novel metabolites and influencing the material properties of industrial landscapes.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Observations reveal that mycotoxin-producing fungi thrive in the humid environments surrounding edible herb farms, where irrigation systems and polytunnel infrastructure facilitate the growth of mycelium. Advanced spectroscopic methods, such as Ultraperformance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy (FT-NIR), enable rapid detection and quantification of mycotoxins like aflatoxin B1, ochratoxin A, and patulin in herb samples. Microbial assemblages on herb leaves, including bacteria and fungi, interact with industrial materials, such as polyethylene mulch, which can leach chemicals into the soil, thereby influencing the distribution and concentration of mycotoxins. The presence of mycotoxins in edible herbs poses a significant risk to human health, particularly for vulnerable populations, and highlights the need for regular monitoring and mitigation strategies to prevent contamination. Environmental factors, including temperature, humidity, and soil composition, also impact the prevalence and production of mycotoxins, underscoring the complexity of mycotoxin dynamics in agricultural systems.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: Alterations in glucose metabolism are known to influence cellular behavior, and research has demonstrated that hyperglycemic conditions can modulate the response of various cell types to different stimuli. In the context of cancer biology, high glucose levels have been shown to promote tumor growth, angiogenesis, and metastasis. This study investigated the impact of hyperglycemic conditions on the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol, which are produced by certain Fusarium species.   The results indicate that hyperglycemic conditions enhance the sensitivity of colon cancer cells to alternariol and deoxynivalenol, leading to increased cell death and inhibition of proliferation. Conversely, normoglycemic conditions mitigate this effect, suggesting that high glucose levels may compromise cellular defenses against these mycotoxins. The findings have implications for understanding the role of glucose metabolism in modulating the sensitivity of cancer cells to environmental toxins and may inform the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations of industrial landscapes reveal that fungal growths are ubiquitous, exhibiting rapid proliferation on concrete surfaces, steel beams, and asphalt roads. These mycological assemblages have adapted to thrive in environments with high levels of pollutants, heavy metals, and synthetic chemicals. For example, the fungus Aspergillus, commonly found in urban environments, can develop resistance to antifungal treatments, making it a persistent threat to human health, particularly in patients with compromised immune systems, such as those with severe burn injuries. Conversely, certain species of fungi, like those in the genus Fusarium, have been shown to degrade industrial pollutants, such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), indicating a capacity for bioremediation. However, these beneficial interactions are often overshadowed by the detrimental effects of invasive mold infections, which can spread rapidly through hospital environments, highlighting the complex interplay between human and nonhuman entities in these settings.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Research in the area of human-nonhuman interactions reveals complex dynamics between fungal pathogens and industrial infrastructure. Studies on Aspergillus fumigatus, a common airborne fungus, demonstrate that certain strains exhibiting TR34-mediated resistance exhibit altered phenotypes in response to azole antimycotics. These altered phenotypes are influenced by individual cyp51A single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof, which affect the fungus's susceptibility to azole treatment. Notably, some cyp51A SNPs and combinations demonstrate increased resistance to azole compounds when exposed to industrial materials such as copper or PVC. This phenomenon highlights the interconnectedness of fungal pathogens and human-made environments, revealing novel avenues for research in the Anthropocene.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of contaminated industrial sites reveal a novel antifungal compound produced by bacteria in symbiotic relationship with fungi, specifically Aspergillus fumigatus. This compound, isolated from soil samples, targets the fungal cell wall and cell membrane, causing cellular lysis and oxidative stress. Its broad-spectrum efficacy suggests a potential application in mitigating fungal growth in industrial environments. Further analysis indicates that this compound is induced in response to industrial pollutants, such as heavy metals and polyaromatic hydrocarbons, which disrupt microbial communities. The observed antifungal activity is a nonhuman response to human infrastructure, highlighting the complex and dynamic interactions between industrial materials and microbial assemblages.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations of industrial sites reveal the proliferation of fungal pathogens, such as Fusarium, which have been exacerbated by human infrastructure. In laboratory settings, copper sulfide (CuS) nanoparticles have been found to stimulate immunity in tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum) against fungal infections. The copper-based nanoparticles interact with plant cells, inducing a range of defense responses, including enhanced production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the activation of plant defense-related genes. These CuS nanoparticles also exhibit antimicrobial properties, capable of inhibiting the growth of Fusarium and other fungal pathogens. When integrated into agricultural systems, these nanoparticles may provide a novel approach to managing fungal diseases in crops, thereby mitigating the impact of these pathogens on food security.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations in the Anthropocene reveal a site of environmental rupture where human infrastructure intersects with nonhuman responses. Industrial materials such as concrete and steel provide a substrate for the growth of microorganisms, including fungi like Fusarium graminearum. Research on this fungus has led to the identification of novel compounds with antifungal properties, potentially disrupting multispecies assemblages. Studies have shown that Fusarium graminearum can interact with industrial materials, including low-temperature sterilized concrete, to produce secondary metabolites with varying levels of toxicity. These findings highlight the complex dynamics of human-nonhuman interactions in the Anthropocene, where industrial landscapes become a site of microbial experimentation.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: The research centers on the genetic modification of the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11, with a particular emphasis on the homologous overexpression of phosphatidate phosphatase (Lipin). This manipulation appears to induce significant enhancements in lipid accumulation within the fungus, particularly under static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation conditions. The findings suggest that the overexpression of Lipin leads to increased phosphatidate phosphatase activity, which in turn results in the redirection of carbon flux towards lipid synthesis. Examination of the fungus's metabolic pathways reveals a notable shift in the allocation of resources, with a corresponding increase in the accumulation of lipids. The research implies that the strategic manipulation of Lipin expression may provide a valuable means of improving lipid production in oleaginous fungi, potentially with applications in biofuel and bioproduct development.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Research findings reveal that Aspergillus species, including Aspergillus fumigatus, exhibit unprecedented adaptability and diversity in response to industrial pollutants and altered environments. In areas surrounding chemical manufacturing facilities, Aspergillus populations display increased resistance to antifungal medications, underscoring the molecular shifts that occur when these fungi interact with anthropogenic pollutants. Fungal genomes in these regions exhibit enhanced expression of genes related to heavy metal detoxification, mercury resistance, and altered phosphate transport, suggesting a reorganization of cellular processes in response to industrial byproducts. Furthermore, Aspergillus species demonstrate a capacity to degrade and assimilate a wide range of synthetic compounds, including plastics and petroleum-based pollutants, highlighting the potential for these fungi to drive the breakdown of human-made materials. The proliferation of Aspergillus species in these environments underscores the complex, multifaceted nature of human-fungal interactions, where the boundaries between environmental, industrial, and clinical ecosystems are increasingly blurred.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: Observations of multispecies assemblages in the vicinity of industrial waste sites have revealed the production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) mycotoxins in clinical fungal isolates, particularly Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus terreus. The presence of heavy metals and industrial pollutants in these environments appears to stimulate the production of these mycotoxins, which have been shown to have immunosuppressive effects on humans. In areas surrounding refineries and industrial facilities, the concentration of pollutants such as cadmium and chromium correlates with increased mycotoxin production by fungal isolates. The interaction between industrial pollutants and fungal species gives rise to the emergence of novel mycotoxin-producing strains with potentially enhanced virulence. This phenomenon underscores the complex dynamics of multispecies assemblages in the Anthropocene and highlights the need for further research into the environmental drivers of mycotoxin production.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: Observations at coastal sites reveal pronounced effects of industrial materials on marine ecosystems. Decades of pollution have resulted in the adaptation of native organisms, such as the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512, to produce novel secondary metabolites. These compounds, decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, display potent antibacterial and cytotoxic properties, likely mediated by interactions with heavy metals and industrial contaminants. Analysis of the fungus's habitats indicates a correlation between its growth and the presence of oil spills and other petrochemical anomalies. The fungus's metabolic responses to these anomalies suggest a complex interplay between multispecies assemblages, implicating a role for microbial communities in the degradation and transformation of industrial pollutants.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of nonhuman responses to human infrastructure reveal complex assemblages that subvert design intent. In industrial landscapes, fungi rapidly colonize and degrade materials such as asphalt, steel, and concrete. In a decommissioned oil refinery, toxic chemicals seep into surrounding soil, fostering symbiotic relationships between bacteria and metal ions, resulting in accelerated corrosion. Similarly, within a high-traffic urban area, fungal growth on subway infrastructure is facilitated by organic matter trapped in crevices and cracks, reinforcing the notion that nonhuman agencies can normalize and transform urban environments. In a laboratory setting, a newly developed convolutional neural network facilitated accurate mold identification from smartphone-based imaging, highlighting the potential for accessible, low-cost diagnostics in addressing environmental rupture sites.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Research findings indicate that the gene GSNOR plays a crucial role in maintaining nitric oxide homeostasis within the fungus Aspergillus flavus. This organism is a common producer of aflatoxins, toxic compounds that can have detrimental effects on human and animal health. Aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity are linked to the regulation of nitric oxide levels by GSNOR. In the presence of industrial materials and landscapes, Aspergillus flavus populations can exploit these environments to produce aflatoxins, which can then be transferred to humans through food or other vectors. The fungus's ability to thrive in these settings highlights the complex interactions between industrial infrastructure and multispecies assemblages, where the regulation of nitric oxide homeostasis by GSNOR is a key factor in the pathogenicity and ecological success of Aspergillus flavus.
